a:6:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{55143bb44ec3be435a1b0cf9}s:11:"dateCreated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1427389364;s:4:"usec";i:0;}s:5:"title";s:56:"Humana’s Agent Conduct and Compliance Training Modules";s:4:"date";s:8:"03/26/15";s:3:"uri";s:54:"/humanas-agent-conduct-and-compliance-training-modules";s:7:"content";s:1122:"

Understanding legal and regulatory requirements, such as licensing requirements, is critically important to your success as an agent. Humana is dedicated to providing its agents the tools they need to succeed, which is why they established specific Agent Conduct and Compliance training modules.

These training modules are optional resources and are not mandatory; however, Humana wants to strongly encourage agents to take advantage of them. You may feel you already know the requirements around licensing but their experience has shown that many agents don’t completely understand the laws that apply to their ability to sell insurance. With a minimum time commitment on your part, you will help avoid potential fines, loss of producer contracts, loss of income and help ensure your clients receive the best possible service from a licensed insurance professional.

Please refer to these directions for information on how to access the training through the Agent Portal.

a:6:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{55143f7c4ec3be3d5b1b0cf9}s:11:"dateCreated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1427390332;s:4:"usec";i:0;}s:5:"title";s:45:"Humana: Tax Penalty Special Enrollment Period";s:4:"date";s:8:"03/26/15";s:3:"uri";s:45:"/humana-tax-penalty-special-enrollment-period";s:7:"content";s:2515:"

The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) has announced a Tax Penalty Special Enrollment Period (SEP) for select individuals that have not enrolled in healthcare coverage for 2015. This Special Enrollment Period for Health Insurance Marketplace enrollments only will be from Sunday, March 15 to Thursday, April 30. For an individual to be eligible to enroll during this period, they must meet the below criteria.

  • Must not have purchased coverage for 2015 through the Health Insurance Marketplace
  • Have or are paying the mandate penalty for not having healthcare coverage in 2014
  • Must attest that they only became aware of the mandate penalty after the end of the 2015 Open Enrollment Period on February 15, 2015

Enrollments completed during this special enrollment will have regular coverage effective dates. This means that enrollments completed before the 15th of the month will receive a coverage effective date of the 1st day of the following month. Those completed after the 15th of the month will receive a coverage effective date of the 1st day of the month directly after the following month.

Kentucky and Colorado
The state run Marketplace for Kentucky, has also announced a Tax Penalty Special Enrollment Period for individuals. The qualifying criteria for individuals will be the same as the Health Insurance Marketplace; however the dates for the Special Enrollment Period will vary by state as listed below. At this time, Colorado has not released details on a Special Enrollment Period for individuals and we will provide an update once it is finalized.

  • Kentucky: Monday, March 2nd – Thursday, April 30th

  • Colorado: N/A as of 3/6/2015

Helpful Marketing Materials
Humana has pre-approved customizable marketing flyers especially for the Tax Penalty SEP. You can download, customize and print all materials yourself by clicking the links below. The printed materials can then be left with local tax preparers who could possibly refer individuals that will benefit directly from this SEP. It is simple and easy and could be beneficial with future enrollments.

  • Generic State (except for Kentucky and Colorado) Flyer
  • Kentucky Flyer
";}

a:6:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{5514419a4ec3be3c5b1b0cf9}s:11:"dateCreated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1427390874;s:4:"usec";i:0;}s:5:"title";s:85:"Humana: FastApp Technology, 2015 Medicare Sales Materials Survey and Rewards Programs";s:4:"date";s:8:"03/26/15";s:3:"uri";s:84:"/humana-fastapp-technology-2015-medicare-sales-materials-survey-and-rewards-programs";s:7:"content";s:4342:"

Use of FastApp Technology and Acceptable E-Signatures
As a company, Humana encourages agents to utilize the various electronic enrollment methods available to them. Enrolling your beneficiaries via an electronic enrollment method such as MAPA, iMAPA, or FastApp reduces application errors, reduces pends, and allows enrollments to be processed in a more efficient manner. However, there are certain guidelines that you must follow in order to ensure that the application is collected and signed in a compliant and legal manner.

This communication focuses on the Humana FastApp, accessible by agents through the agent workbench at humana.com, in conjunction with use of the electronic signature (e-sig) method. The e-sig process requires each person signing an application to use their own unique email address. This framework is in accordance with Federal ESIGNA legislation surrounding the capture and use of electronic signature methods. The application, as a contract between Humana and the beneficiary, must meet all requirements to be in compliance with the laws governing such enrollment methods.

When completing an application via FastApp on behalf of one of their clients must

  • Use the beneficiary’s email address, not the agent’s or agency’s email address.
  • Ensure that each email address used to facilitate the e-signature is unique to an individual beneficiary and no one else.

Shared email addresses are not permitted to be used. If an individual enrollee does not have an email address or if a husband and wife does not have two distinct email addresses, an alternate enrollment method MUST be used. No exceptions permitted. To reinforce this messaging, Humana will be further strengthening the disclaimer that you must confirm before proceeding with the e-signature option on a FastApp enrollment.

Humana will be conducting monthly monitoring to determine if applications have been submitted inappropriately and taking the necessary steps to address the issue. Agents, where it is determined that he/she willfully and with intent neglected and/or ignored the disclaimer, will be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment or contract.

2015 Medicare Sales Material Survey
As a part of Humana’s continued effort to improve their sales efficiencies, Humana’s Marketing Department would like to gather some feedback from the 2015 Sales Material.

This link will take you to the 2015 Medicare Marketing Sales Survey. The survey is 20 questions and should only take 5-10 minutes to complete and your responses are completely anonymous. Your responses will be used to develop the 2016 AEP Sales Collateral, so please be candid. Feedback from the agent community is the key to creating effective sales material so please take the time to provide your input.

Promoting Rewards Programs to Prospective Customers
On September 30, 2014 Humana announced a change in the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) 2015 marketing guidance regarding the promotion of reward programs to prospective members. In the past, CMS did not allow agents to discuss rewards programs with a prospective enrollee until they became an active member. CMS changed their guidance in 2014 to allow agents to discuss rewards programs to prospective members and during sales events. Humana currently has two rewards programs available in select markets, “HumanaVitality” and “Humana Healthy Rewards.”

HumanaVitality is a wellness program that helps members understand their current health status and allows members to set goals to maintain or improve their overall health. They’ll also receive suggestions on recommended activities to help them reach their goals and earn “Vitality Bucks” that can be used to purchase health and wellness items to help them stay motivated.

With Humana Healthy Rewards members are rewarded for getting preventative healthcare screenings and tests. When members complete four of the eligible screenings and tests from a specific list, they get to choose from a number of gift cards.

";}

a:6:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{551441da4ec3be3b5b1b0cf9}s:11:"dateCreated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1427390938;s:4:"usec";i:538000;}s:5:"title";s:46:"Assurant Health Qualifying Life Events Updates";s:4:"date";s:19:"03/26/15 01:28:58pm";s:3:"uri";s:47:"/assurant-health-qualifying-life-events-updates";s:7:"content";s:2048:"

Qualifying Life Event Application Submission Information

For most Qualifying Life Events, applications must be submitted within the 60 days after the Qualifying Life Event date. Applications submitted before the Qualifying Life Event date will not be accepted and you must resubmit a new application. It may appear that the application has been accepted when submitted electronically on the Assurant Health sales site; however, the application will be marked as not eligible once the Enrollment department receives it.

  • Exceptions apply. Please see the updated Qualifying Life Event guide on the Assurant Health sales site for complete details

Paper applications must be received by the Assurant Health Enrollment department within five days of the application signed date or the application will not be accepted.

Qualifying Life Event applications for renewals cannot have an effective date prior to Qualifying Life Event date.

In regards to renewals:

  • Can submit the application up to 30 days in advance of the renewal date (QLE date)
  • If the application is submitted before or on the QLE date, the first available effective date is the first of the month following the QLE
  • If the application is submitted after the QLE date, general submission rules apply

Additional Special Enrollment does not apply to off-Marketplace sales.

Customers who have paid a tax penalty for 2014 and attest they were not aware of the penalty have a Special Enrollment Period through healthcare.gov between March 15, 2015, and April 30, 2015, 11:59 p.m. ET, if they do not already have coverage. The Marketplace will verify the penalty and determine eligibility. This additional Special Enrollment does not apply to customers who purchase their plan through the Assurant Health sales site.

";}

a:6:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{5514429a4ec3be3d5b1b0cfa}s:11:"dateCreated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1427391130;s:4:"usec";i:930000;}s:5:"title";s:69:"Humana: Cash Premium Payment Option Extended to Dollar General Stores";s:4:"date";s:19:"03/26/15 01:32:10pm";s:3:"uri";s:69:"/humana-cash-premium-payment-option-extended-to-dollar-general-stores";s:7:"content";s:1666:"

New Cash Premium Payment Option Expanded to Dollar General Stores
The barcode based bill-pay service which allows Humana’s individual medical/dental members to make their monthly premium payments with cash, has now been expanded to include Dollar General store locations. Members can chose to make their payments at either a CVS Pharmacy or Dollar General Store location using the barcoded invoice.

Cash Premium Payment Option Now Available in Colorado
Members who receive a paper invoice in Colorado will begin seeing the cash payment option starting with their April invoice. Members should receive a barcoded invoice in mid-March. Dollar General is the only retailer participating in the program in Colorado. Members can utilize the store locator found below.

Members in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Kentucky, Louisiana, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, Ohio, Tennessee, Texas and Utah can continue to use the barcode at either CVS Pharmacy or Dollar General Stores.

Important to Know

  • This is not available for Humana Medicare, Medicaid or Employer Group members
  • This is available for on-exchange and select off-exchange plans in approved states
  • There is no charge to the member for making cash payments to Humana through this bill-pay service at participating CVS Pharmacy or Dollar General locations

Location Finders

  • CVS Pharmacy
  • Dollar General

a:6:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{5514436c4ec3be3b5b1b0cfa}s:11:"dateCreated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1427391340;s:4:"usec";i:250000;}s:5:"title";s:66:"Humana’s Agent Center of Excellence Announces Agent Direct Email";s:4:"date";s:8:"03/26/15";s:3:"uri";s:64:"/humanas-agent-center-of-excellence-announces-agent-direct-email";s:7:"content";s:2873:"

To better support and simplify Humana’s relationship with you, they are pleased to announce an addition to their agent contact solution. One phone number, recently introduced, is now being complemented by a secure email solution exclusively for your service and support needs.

Humana’s goal is to simplify your service experience and drive rapid response and consistency by providing you with:

  • One point of contact – secure email or phone allowing you to use the solution that works for you
  • A dedicated team of service professionals whose only job is to provide you service and support
  • The ability to track and trend issues
  • Root cause investigation and prevention in the future

Humana is excited to launch this secure email solution to simplify and improve your service and support experience. This will allow you to spend more time inspiring the health and well-being of the lives you touch and influence.

Agent Center of Excellence Contact Information

  • Toll Free: 800-592-3005
  • Email Address:SBMarketSupport@humana.com

Types of inquires that can be sent to Agent Center of Excellence

  • Claims
  • Member Eligibility
  • Billing and Enrollment Inquiries
  • ID Cards
  • HumanaVitality

Types of inquiries that should not be sent to Agent Center of Excellence

  • Enrollment transactions such as new hires, change forms and termination requests – should be sent to the fax number or enrolled online
  • Plan adds/changes
  • Commissions and Licensing
  • Quoting

For HIPPA authentication, please have the following information available when you call, or include in the body of your email:

  • Agent Tax ID or SAN (Humana System Assigned Number)
    • Tax ID/SAN or email domain must match what Humana has on file when sending via email
  • Group Number
  • Group Mailing Address Zip Code

If inquiring about a member:

  • Agent Tax ID or SAN (Humana System Assigned Number)
    • Tax ID/SAN or email domain must match what Humana has on file when sending via email
  • Any 3 of the following:
    • Member ID/Full Member Name
    • Date of Birth
    • Group Number
    • Member Zip Code

If inquiring about a claim:

  • Agent Tax ID or SAN (Humana System Assigned Number)
    • Tax ID/SAN or email domain must match what Humana has on file when sending via email
  • Any 3 of the following:
    • Date of Service
    • Provider
    • Claim Dollar Amount
    • Claim Number

a:10:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{551443bc4ec3be685b1b0cf9}s:11:"dateCreated";a:2:{s:3:"sec";i:1429206121;s:4:"usec";i:517000;}s:11:"dateUpdated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1439504499;s:4:"usec";i:0;}s:20:"dateUpdatedFormatted";s:8:"08/13/15";s:9:"updatedBy";s:9:"Bob Jones";s:5:"title";s:73:"HumanaOne: Updated Forms & Applications for Financial Protection Products";s:4:"date";s:8:"04/16/15";s:3:"uri";s:71:"/humanaone-updated-forms-applications-for-financial-protection-products";s:7:"content";s:2339:"

Updated Forms and Applications for Humana Financial Protection Products
As of February 27, 2015, new application forms for Humana’s Financial Protection Products (HFPP) have been updated and are available through the Agent Work Bench and www.humana.com as well as their online and telephonic application processes. The enrollment team will cease accepting old paper applications as of March 31, 2015.

Beginning April 1, 2015, paper applications must be completed on the new application forms.

Please destroy all old enrollment forms and begin using the new application form for all HFPP products. Humana does not accept Cash with Applications (check, money order, etc.) – this practice was discontinued in July 2013. Doing this will avoid delays and added steps for the enrollment team processing paper applications for the below impacted states and form numbers.

  • Cash Cancer, form number 71128: AL, AR, AZ, CO, HI, IA, ID, IL, IN, KS, KY, LA, MI, MN, MO, MS, NC, NE, NM, OH, OK, OR, SC, TN, TX, WI, WV
  • Critical Illness, form number 71127: AL, AR, AZ, CA, CO, FL, GA, HI, IA, ID, IL, IN, KS, KY, LA, MI, MO, MS, NC, NE, NM, NV, OH, OK, OR, PA, SC, TN, TX, UT, WA, WI, WV
  • Junior Estate Builder, form number 71125: AL, AR, AZ, CA, CO, DC, FL, GA, HI, IA, ID, IL, IN, KS, KY, LA, MI, MO, MS, NC, NE, NM, NV, OH, OK, OR, PA, SC, TN, TX, UT, WI, WV
  • Memorial Fund, form number 71126: AL, AR, AZ, CA, CO, FL, GA, HI, IA, ID, IL, IN, KS, KY, LA, MI, MN, MO, MS, NC, NE, NM, NV, OH, OK, OR, PA, SC, TN, TX, UT, VA, WI, WV
  • Payment Authorization, form number GN 71123

While Humana will accept the old paper applications through March 31, 2015, when they process them into the Humana system, the system displays the new form (similar to what happens when you complete an online or telephonic application). The Humana staff will contact the applicants to complete the new fields and health survey questions. Once completed, Humana will send out the new forms for the applicant to sign.

Forms, Applications and the HFPP Agent Guide can be found by accessing the Agent Workbench (AWB) home page and selecting the link for “Ordering Marketing Materials and Plan Summaries.”

a:7:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{5548e86a4ec3bed5791b0b81}s:11:"dateCreated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1430841450;s:4:"usec";i:144000;}s:5:"title";s:47:"Assurant Health Exiting Health Insurance Market";s:4:"date";s:8:"05/05/15";s:3:"uri";s:48:"/assurant-health-exiting-health-insurance-market";s:7:"content";s:2367:"

Assurant Health wants to share a recent announcement made by Assurant Health’s parent company, Assurant, Inc. Following a strategic review of its portfolio of businesses, Assurant has decided to focus on housing and lifestyle specialty protection products and services.

With this decision, Assurant, Inc. will explore options for two of its business units, Assurant Health and Assurant Employee Benefits, including a separate sale of each business. Assurant believes there are better owners for each business with more focused health care and benefits portfolios.

Absent a sale of Assurant Health, Assurant, Inc. will begin the process to exit the health insurance market this year for all of its product offerings, and will not participate in the next Affordable Care Act Open Enrollment period in November. Assurant’s exit will be substantially complete in 2016.

At this time, Assurant Health continues to accept new business in all product lines, and there are no changes to your clients’ policies and benefits, nor to your appointment or commissions with Assurant Health.

Throughout the process ahead, they will uphold their commitments to their customers, and continue to support their valued agent partners. While Assurant Health can’t speculate on how long this process will take or the outcome, as the process moves along and more information is available, they will be sending updates.

E Broker Center firmly agrees that Assurant Health will cease offering advanced commissions in the next few weeks. It is important that you look at the alternative carriers that we have offered. To date AIG, GTL, SLAICO and Cigna Supplemental are the three carriers that have a full array supplemental products.  

";s:4:"tags";a:2:{i:0;s:8:"Assurant";i:1;s:6:"public";}}

a:7:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{5548e9f74ec3bec97a1b0b81}s:11:"dateCreated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1430841847;s:4:"usec";i:490000;}s:5:"title";s:68:"ER visits up under Obamacare despite promises, doctors’ poll finds";s:4:"date";s:8:"05/05/15";s:3:"uri";s:65:"/er-visits-up-under-obamacare-despite-promises-doctors-poll-finds";s:7:"content";s:6448:"

Doctors say emergency room visits have increased since the advent of Obamacare, undercutting one of the key selling points of President Obama’s health care law, which was supposed to ensure a healthier population by pushing consumers to rely on their primary physicians rather than emergency trips to the hospital.

Three out of four ER doctors said they have seen a rise in the number of patients since January 2014, when Obamacare fully kicked in, according to a survey conducted by the American College of Emergency Physicians. More than a quarter of the doctors said they have seen a major surge, and 47 percent said the rise has been slight.

The doctors said they fear a spike in visits could overwhelm their resources: Seven out of 10 said their departments aren’t prepared for a significant increase in patient volume.

The biggest cause is a lack of primary care doctors to treat the increased number of patients with health care coverage, so the patients are turning to the emergency room instead — exactly what wasn’t supposed to happen.

“Just because people have health insurance does not mean they have access to timely medical care,” said Michael Gerardi, president of the American College of Emergency Physicians.

Some patients also may be in the habit of turning to emergency rooms or have a hard time getting away from work for daytime checkups.


“There’s such a hassle factor in making an appointment,” said Avik Roy, a senior fellow at the conservative Manhattan Institute. “It’s just a lot easier to show up at the emergency room.”

Mr. Obama vowed that his health care plan would make a dent in the high rate of emergency room visits, particularly for the uninsured. Siphoning these patients to primary care doctors was expected to cut overall costs by catching health problems earlier and by diverting patients away from more expensive emergency room care.

The Health and Human Services Department, which is overseeing implementation of the Affordable Care Act, said it’s trying to get patients to change their habits while broadening primary care options.

“For people who have utilized emergency rooms for non-emergency care in the past, we are continuing to work to reach out and provide information on how to best use their new coverage,” said Aaron Albright, a spokesman for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. “The Affordable Care Act is also making critical investments to train more doctors and nurses, especially in communities that have lacked access to quality, affordable care in the past.”

The poll, conducted in March, had 2,099 respondents and a margin of error of 2.1 percentage points. Doctors from three large states — California, Texas and New York — accounted for a quarter of the responses.

A majority of the doctors said they are seeing more Medicaid patients in the ER.

Millions of people have been added to the rolls of Medicaid, which is the federal-state health care program for the poor, but beneficiaries are struggling to find doctors willing to accept the relatively low reimbursements the program offers.

Because Obamacare covers emergency room visits, showing up at a hospital is a viable option for more people.

Obamacare critics said the poll results were not surprising.

A study published right as Obamacare’s individual mandate took effect in 2014 found Oregonians who obtained Medicaid benefits in a 2008 lottery used emergency rooms at a 40 percent higher rate than did people who remained uninsured.

According to its authors, “basic economic theory suggests that by reducing the out-of-pocket cost of a visit that an uninsured person would face, Medicaid coverage should increase use of the emergency department.”

Another study, however, found a modest decrease in ER visits in 2011 among young adults who were able to stay on their parents’ plans until age 26 because of Obamacare.

Still to be seen is whether the results are just a blip. Caroline Pearson, a vice president at the Avalere Health consultancy, said she expects insurers to do “a fair amount of outreach and care management” to get their Obamacare customers to change their ER habits.

In a speech Monday, HHS Secretary Sylvia Mathews Burwell credited Obamacare for a $7.4 billion decrease in 2014 in what is known as uncompensated care — the unreimbursed cost of care provided by hospitals to people who are uninsured or underinsured.

However, she said, there is “still more work to do to make sure consumers know how to use their insurance, to connect their coverage with their care.”

Analysts said Ms. Burwell’s comments don’t contradict the poll’s findings, which focused on patient volume during Obamacare’s short run and did not dive into their insurance status.

Although uncompensated costs may be declining, Mr. Roy said, it is important to note how much money the government spent to achieve that result.

Obamacare’s framers he said, replaced “one free-rider program” with another through a massive increase in federal spending on government-subsidized insurance.

A chunk of that spending is the subject of a Supreme Court ruling due by June.

The justices will decide whether the IRS has been unlawfully paying the subsidies to customers in at least 34 states that decided not to set up their own Obamacare exchanges. In those cases, the federal government has stepped in to set up the insurance marketplaces — but the way the Affordable Care Act is written, it’s not clear whether customers in those states are eligible for the subsidies.

If the subsidies are struck down, coverage could become unaffordable for millions of people.

In that scenario, 42 percent of physicians said they would expect ER visits to increase, 31 percent said the number would stay the same and 10 percent said ER visits would decrease, according to Monday’s poll.

About two-thirds said their reimbursements for providing emergency care would decrease if the federal subsidies are taken away from their states.


";s:4:"tags";a:2:{i:0;s:9:"obamacare";i:1;s:6:"public";}}

a:7:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{5548fa824ec3be5a7f1b0b81}s:11:"dateCreated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1430846104;s:4:"usec";i:409000;}s:5:"title";s:64:"Sales Advice: Medicare Supplement and Part D Make a Great Couple";s:4:"date";s:19:"05/05/15 01:15:04pm";s:3:"uri";s:64:"/sales-advice-medicare-supplement-and-part-d-make-a-great-couple";s:7:"content";s:3595:"

Batman and Robin.  Peanut butter and jelly. Medicare Supplement and Medicare Part D.

These things go together. Or at least they should. Unfortunately, many agents are missing the opportunity to link a Medicare Supplement sale with a prescription drug plan (PDP). Instead, they give their client a website or a phone number and send them on their way. When this happens, agents lose the chance to serve clients better, make themselves more valuable and boost their bottom line.

Medicare Supplement plans are sold year round by Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield (Anthem). They are popular because they fill the holes in Original Medicare while providing broad access and predictable costs. However, it’s important to remember that they don’t cover everything. Everyone who purchases a Medicare Supplement plan also needs to buy a Part D Prescription Drug plan (also known as a PDP).

Here are just a few reasons why agents will want to capture both of these sales together when they have the chance:

Become a one-stop destination. Customers want the convenience of doing all their insurance business at the same time and place. By coupling Medicare Supplement and Part D, you give them a go-to destination and person.

Set yourself apart from the competition. As long as some agents are neglecting the prescription drug business with the Medicare Supplement sale, you can differentiate yourself by filling this important need.

Meet your clients’ needs. Your clients need both medical and drug coverage, but Medicare can be confusing, especially for people aging into it for the first time. You can help direct beneficiaries through this maze, helping them find the best coverage at the lowest cost, including matching them with the drug coverage they need. By doing so, you increase your standing in their eyes, making them more likely to refer family and friends to you in the future.

Keep them coming back. Medicare beneficiaries tend to buy a supplemental plan and stick with it. That becomes even more likely when buyers add a prescription drug plan to their purchase. In contrast, if a beneficiary leaves your business in search of a PDP plan somewhere else, then it becomes more likely that they will take the rest of their business with them.

Boost your bottom line. Commissions can add up over time for those agents who are able to successfully sell PDP plans with most Medicare Supplement plans. Assuming the typical payment structure for the original sale, plus annual renewals, an agent with a book of 50 PDP clients would earn roughly $10,000 over a six-year period. So investing a little time up front could pay off nicely in the end.

So there is the case for pairing Medicare Supplement with a PDP. It may take a touch of training, practice and patience to incorporate this into your process. Eventually, you’ll be glad you did when you make yourself a more valuable resource to your clients, earn referrals and differentiate yourself from your competitors.

Note: Agents must have current licensure, certification and appointment in every state they sell in to be eligible for commission payment of sales. If cross selling does occur, the scope of appointment process and guidance must be followed with beneficiaries. Cross selling is not allowed in Ohio, unless the person is already an Anthem Medicare Supplement member.

";s:4:"tags";a:4:{i:0;s:5:"sales";i:1;s:8:"medicare";i:2;s:10:"supplement";i:3;s:6:"public";}}

a:7:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{5548fb404ec3be447f1b0b81}s:11:"dateCreated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1430846272;s:4:"usec";i:49000;}s:5:"title";s:57:"Successful D-SNP Marketing (How to Target Dual Eligibles)";s:4:"date";s:8:"05/05/15";s:3:"uri";s:56:"/successful-d-snp-marketing-how-to-target-dual-eligibles";s:7:"content";s:4538:"

Did you know there are over 9 million elderly and disabled Americans enrolled in both Medicare and Medicaid (aka “dual eligible”)?  This represents a tremendous opportunity to market Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield’s Dual-Eligible Special Needs Plans (D-SNPs)! Successful marketing of D-SNPs requires a unique approach. Here are some marketing strategies and tips for targeting the dual-eligible population!

Grassroots Marketing Strategy

Grassroots marketing is deemed the most effective method for selling D-SNPs. Informal events (e.g., kiosk in a pharmacy) have generated quality leads for some of the most successful agents.

There are two primary components to grassroots marketing: (1) establishing a presence in strategic locations; and (2) building relationships with influential partners.

1.      Establish a Presence

To win in the D-SNP market, you have to be out in the community and establish your presence. Your continued presence helps build your credibility as a competent professional and enables people to feel comfortable approaching you. In order to effectively reach this market, consider building relationships with low-cost retail stores, food pantries, homeless shelters, check-cashing services, utility assistance offices and faith-based locations.

When working with community service providers, partner with management, event organizers, and other staff to align your time with their community activities, targeting events and holidays, and coordinating your table theme with the community event.

If you don’t know where to start, try conducting an online search by state/county. You are sure to find a wealth of information, services, location sites and hours of operation. In addition, your local Broker Support representative can help you identify sites and obtain clearance to market at those locations!

2.      Build Relationships With Influential Partners (i.e., Cultivate Centers of Influence)

Relationships with organizations and professionals can help generate referrals for you, acting as your Centers of Influence and helping you grow your business. Examples of these professionals/organizations include health care providers, welfare counselors, faith-based organizations, senior centers and low-income or subsidized housing communities.

Grassroots Marketing Tips (tips for targeting the dual-eligible population)

  • Conduct informal events in areas where the Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield provider network is strong and where there is a higher concentration of dual eligible.
  • Establish a partnership with the retailer or service provider. Explain how your presence in their establishment will be mutually beneficial. Assure them you will not solicit customers but will simply provide information should they approach you.
  • Schedule your event early in the month at a retail location when the store will be visited more frequently or later in the month at community service providers, such as food banks.
  • Make your table stand out from the products and advertising in the store.
  • Consider offering a prize or giveaway that will attract potential customers to your table.  (Ideas: prize wheel; buy and use products from the store as giveaways; provide commodities as giveaways such as laundry detergent or soap). You must be clear that there is no obligation required to win a prize, and make sure that it’s offered to everyone equally.
  • Become familiar with the general layout of the store/location so you can point customers in the right direction. This can go a long way toward establishing your credibility as a trusted source of helpful and reliable information.
  • When planning your event, be sure to consider traffic, bus routes, mail stops, and community events.


Remember, regardless of the marketing approach or location(s) you choose, you must be familiar with and follow the Medicare Marketing Guidelines for all events. That includes filing your event with CMS, following guidelines for giveaways and prizes, and providing information only, rather than soliciting customers.

a:7:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{554926844ec3be81021b0b8b}s:11:"dateCreated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1430857348;s:4:"usec";i:694000;}s:5:"title";s:101:"States wasting millions by keeping ineligible recipients on ObamaCare’s Medicaid rolls, critics say";s:4:"date";s:8:"05/05/15";s:3:"uri";s:98:"/states-wasting-millions-by-keeping-ineligible-recipients-on-obamacares-medicaid-rolls-critics-say";s:7:"content";s:5983:"

States are wasting millions of taxpayer dollars under ObamaCare's massive Medicaid expansion by failing to regularly check the eligibility of program recipients, critics charge. 

Under the Affordable Care Act, millions of people were enrolled in the expanded Medicaid, a jointly run state and federal program that primarily provides free or low-cost health care to low-income people, the elderly and disabled. Federal law requires that states annually verify the eligibility of recipients -- but some are not, and that means tens of thousands of ineligible people are receiving benefits. 

Arkansas, for instance, has failed to comply with the law, and internal emails from the Arkansas Department of Human Services reveal officials have yet to begin what's known as a "redetermination." 

"We're trying to hold the DHS accountable for the promises they made, and make sure that the people who are on the program actually qualify for it," said state Sen. Bryan King. 

According to emails between King and Arkansas DHS Director John Selig, the state applied for and was issued two waivers from the federal government granting extensions for their "redetermination" deadline. 

But the delay is costing taxpayers money. Selig estimated in a report to a Joint Budget Committee that an eligibility review could remove up to 40,000 people from the state's Medicaid system -- saving taxpayers up to $20 million a month. 

"The fact that they aren't doing this already in a program riddled with cost overruns shows their lack of regard for taxpayer dollars funded by hardworking Americans," said Charles Siler, director of media relations for the Foundation for Government Accountability (FGA). 

A similar situation -- stemming from problems launching ObamaCare websites -- exists in Massachusetts, Siler said, but fiscal watchdogs also blame the federal government for allowing states to miss their deadlines. 

"What Arkansas and Massachusetts tell us is that the Obama administration doesn't care about being responsible with the billions of taxpayer dollars being wasted by ObamaCare's Medicaid expansion," FGA senior fellow Josh Archambault said. "In truth, we have yet to uncover how many other states the feds are allowing to sidestep the law, and these states may simply be the tip of the iceberg." 

In Arkansas, the first DHS waiver extended the review deadline to March, from Dec. 31, 2014, but Selig testified as late as April 20 that his department had been issued another waiver pushing the deadline to September. 

When King requested to see the "waivers," the DHS was unable to provide them. "We're thinking the dog ate their waiver," King said after months of requests. 

But Arkansas DHS communications director Amy Webb provided Fox News with a letter that appears to confirm the extension, dated April 27 from the federal Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS). 

"The deadline to complete those delayed renewals was moved to September 30, 2015," Webb told Fox News. "Knowing that people would feel more comfortable with that in writing, we requested formal confirmation of the September 30th date last week." 

The letter from the CMS states: "CMS is now providing Arkansas with authority ... to delay eligibility renewals scheduled for January 1, 2014 through December 31, 2014 for 9 months, until October 1, 2014 through September 30, 2015." 

Webb said they are in "constant contact" with CMS on their "system development." She said they plan to begin the process "in the next two weeks." 

"They've been misleading us -- that's just the facts," King said. "It seems that they're trying to cover what they should have been doing to begin with. ... And it's wasting money." 

Siler agreed, saying, "They are all too happy to leave on tens of thousands of individuals at the cost of millions of taxpayer dollars per month, than comply with the law and start controlling the exorbitant costs." 

Massachusetts officials blame ACA-required changes in the state's Medicaid enrollment website -- changes that crashed the site -- for its delay in reviewing recipient eligibility. 

Because the website crashed, former Massachusetts Gov. Deval Patrick struck a deal with the Obama administration that allowed more than 320,000 people to be added to the Medicaid expansion program without checking eligibility, Archambault said. 

Archambault estimates that 1.2 million people in Massachusetts still need to have their eligibility verified. 

"They have not completed a redetermination in almost two years," Archambault said. "If the Massachusetts Affordable Care Act website had worked the first time around, state and federal taxpayers would have paid far less than they have now." 

The FGA noted a change from the Patrick administration. Current Massachusetts Gov. Charlie Baker estimates saving $400 million when the redetermination process is completed. 

"Medicaid is a high-risk program," said Carolyn Yocom, director of the health care team at the Government Accountability Office (GAO). "High risk for waste, fraud, and abuse by virtue of its improper payment system." 

Improper payments last year alone totaled about $17.5 billion, Yocom said. 

"CMS continues to face persistent challenges in reducing improper payments, and requires additional leadership commitment to ensure that ongoing efforts - such as working with states to identify and collect improper payments - benefit from reliable data systems that will reduce these," Yocom said.

a:7:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{554926fe4ec3be0e041b0b83}s:11:"dateCreated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1430857470;s:4:"usec";i:76000;}s:5:"title";s:56:"Obamacare's 'risk' program may shake up insurance prices";s:4:"date";s:8:"05/05/15";s:3:"uri";s:54:"/obamacares-risk-program-may-shake-up-insurance-prices";s:7:"content";s:8548:"

When this Obamacare bill comes due, will there be nearly enough money to pay it?

An important tool meant to limit the financial risk of Obamacare insurers is expected to be grossly underfunded and "may make the U.S. insurance market less stable, not more," a new analysis warns.

The amount of money that profitable insurers expect to pay into the program was less than an estimated 10 percent what is expected to be paid out to unprofitable insurers, the Standard & Poor's Ratings Services report found.

The analysis assumes Congress will continue mandating that the program must be self-sustaining from insurers' payments, and not tap government funds.

As a result, some insurers may have a tougher time covering their costs—and Obamacare customers in some areas of the country may face higher premium prices in 2016.

Katrina Wittkamp | Getty Images

"There's a lot of uncertainty, and unless there is clear guidance that comes out, pricing itself for the next year will be a little uncertain from both consumers' perspective and insurers' perspective," said credit analyst Deep Banerjee, one of the authors of the Standard & Poor's report.

That uncertainty relates to the Affordable Care Act's "risk corridor program," which was designed to have insurers share the financial risk of providing health benefits to customers of government-run Obamacare exchanges during the first three years of operation, from 2014 through 2016.

Read MoreBig savings in Obamacare plan

Under the program, insurers that pay out significantly less in benefits to exchange customers than they collect in premiums will pay some money into the risk corridor. In turn, that money is supposed to be paid out in varying degrees to insurers who collected significantly less in premiums than the cost of providing benefits. Insurers whose losses and profits are not substantial neither pay into the risk corridor, nor get money from it.

Not enough money now, or possibly later

The Standard & Poor's report looked at insurers' financial statements and compared the total risk corridor receivables and payables they had booked.

"We estimate that the ACA risk corridor will not receive adequate monies from insurers with profitable exchange business to pay insurers that have unprofitable exchange business," it said.

The report did not identify the total amounts of receivables and payables disclosed, but Banerjee said the deficit would be in the range of several billion dollars.

The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, which administers Obamacare, did not comment when asked about the report. Last year, CMS said that if there is a shortfall in the program, all payments for the current year would be reduced on a pro rata basis "to the extent of the shortfall."

Read MoreBig threat to small biz workers in Obamacare case

Standard & Poor's said that even if CMS then used risk corridor collections from 2015 to first cover the unpaid amounts in 2014, "we do not expect the individual exchange business in 2015 to be profitable enough to offset the deficit from the previous year."

The report notes that it may be possible for CMS to use excess funding from another Obamacare program, if any, to offset some of the deficit, but notes it is "more likely" that CMS will have to adjust the risk corridor scheme "to ensure budget neutrality."

Problem worse than estimated?

No money has yet been paid out under the program.

Banerjee said insurers with businesses that are well-diversified beyond the Obamacare exchanges will be able to easily handle not getting risk corridor payments to which they are entitled.

But for insurers that are heavily concentrated on the exchanges, "not getting the money they think they are supposed to get will have a much bigger impact," Banerjee said.

Read MoreMillennials' baby bust may signal historic shift

A large number of insurers—more than half of the Obamacare exchange issuers—"were conservative" and did not record any risk corridor payments that they might be owed, the report found. "This indicates that the actual aggregate payments due to insurers from the corridor are likely even higher than what has been currently recorded."

If in fact there is a significant amount of receivables that are not being publicly disclosed, that means that the risk corridor program is even more underfunded than S&P estimated in its report, Banerjee said. That's because it's unlikely that insurers are understating the amount of money they have to pay into the risk corridor to nearly the same degree that the receivables are being understated, Banerjee said.

The report went on to argue that "insurers likely didn't record the receivables because they doubt they'll actually receive their eligible corridor payments."

Big exposure for some

In another potentially worrisome sign, a number of insurers had risk corridor receivables that exceeded 50 percent of their reported capital.

PreferredOne, based in Minnesota, booked risk corridor receivables that were 149 percent of the insurer's reported capital. A spokesman for the insurer said, "PreferredOne expects the federal government to meet its risk corridor obligation for all insurers who provided individual health coverage as required by the Affordable Care Act."

Kentucky Health Cooperative had the second-highest level of receivables as a percentage of capital—117 percent. A spokeswoman did not return a call seeking comment.

Oscar Health Insurance, which is based in New York and does business as well in New Jersey, had $15 million worth of receivables, which accounted for 57 percent of reported capital, according to the S&P report.

In a statement, an Oscar spokeswoman said, "Utilizing the latest available information that has been released on the statewide risk pool, Oscar expects its risk corridor receivable to be $9 million."

"The difference from the $15 million cited in Oscar's financial statements is driven by refined expectations of Oscar's relativity to the market risk pool, and not by expected funding issues of the risk corridor program. This number should be held against Oscar's total capital of over $250 million, as opposed to only its capital in New York."

The spokeswoman also said: "CMS has indicated that payments into the risk corridor program in 2015 and 2016 will be used to pay 2014 obligations if the program is underfunded. Reports and industry-internal discussions we follow indicate that insurers will be made whole for 2014 risk corridor receivables, although the precise timing of these payments is uncertain."

Other insurers with relatively high ratios of receivables to capital—Moda Health Plan of Oregon, Common Ground Healthcare and Health Republic Insurance of New York—either had no comment or did not respond to requests for comment.

Earlier this year, an Iowa-based insurer, CoOportunity Health, was taken over by government regulators after claims by customers outweighed its capital. CoOportunity Health had been reporting tens of millions of dollars of risk corridor payments as part of its capital.

April 2015   
Looking for a competitive edge to help you grow your business in 2015? Complete your business profile survey to receive timely information regarding your individual sales opportunities outside of Open Enrollment.
Start the Survey
Direct Access to Health Plan Details

Direct your covered clients to use www.myUHC.com or www.myUHOne.com as online tools to manage their health plans. Whether your client has an On- or Off-Exchange plan, they can look up benefits, locate a doctor, manage claims and more through these helpful sites.

Find more details here
Encourage Your Customers to Work With Their Primary Care Physician (PCP)

If your clients are enrolled in a UnitedHealthcare ACA individual health plan with a network that requires a Primary Care Physician (PCP) here are 3 helpful tips to pass on:
  1. Tell them to see their PCP first. Even if they are undergoing treatment with a different doctor or specialist today, coordinating care through their PCP is key. Your client will receive the greatest benefit from their health plan when they work with their PCP.
  2. Referrals are important, and necessary. A referral can maximize their plan's benefits. Without a referral to see a network specialist or other provider, your client may end up paying the full cost. Network requirements can vary - see the 2015 Producer Guide for more details.
  3. They can change their PCP. If your clients aren't satisfied with their PCP they can request a change themselves or you can request the change for them by calling the Broker Service Center at (800) 474-4467.
Find out which networks require a PCP and read more about the helpful tips above.
Client Social Security Numbers Needed

Starting in January 2016, the IRS will require us to report Minimum Essential Coverage (MEC) for individuals covered anytime during the 2015 tax year by a Golden Rule or UnitedHealthcare Life Insurance Company health plan. To ensure proper matching, we are required to request Social Security Numbers and include those on the report. If you have clients with one of these plans, we will be notifying them by mail and email if we need their SSN. You can help us obtain this information by encouraging your clients to complete and mail this form to:
   Attn: Policy Administration
   PO Box 31372
   Salt Lake City, UT 84131-0372

Ensuring your clients have properly verified SSNs for all individuals covered by their plan will help them avoid a tax penalty in 2016.

a:7:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{554a5b074ec3bed9401b0b83}s:11:"dateCreated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1430936327;s:4:"usec";i:192000;}s:5:"title";s:47:"Important Update About Employer Data Collection";s:4:"date";s:8:"05/06/15";s:3:"uri";s:48:"/important-update-about-employer-data-collection";s:7:"content";s:3923:"

Important Update About Employer Data Collection

Similar information will be shared with employers via special bulletin today.

As mentioned in the April 15 article, we are collecting data from employers to meet reporting requirements. As part of that data collection, we are asking groups to provide or verify their Employer Identification Numbers (EINs) on Blue Access for EmployersSM (BAE).

  • Emails are being sent over the next two weeks. Letters will also be sent to groups who do not have email addresses later in the month. Follow-up emails will be sent in June, and again in July, to groups who have not responded.

Collecting EINs
The preferred method for collecting this data is in BAE. If you have groups unable to use BAE to confirm the EINs, they can call the Dedicated Group Data Collection line at 855-804-3635. They should select “Group,” then “Administrator,” and then select option four “Number” to provide their EIN.

Please use the following Q&A to help address additional questions your groups may have.

Q: Why are you collecting this information?
A: This information helps us to complete certain reports for the government. It is important for each group to report accurate information to us. We are collecting EINs to meet several reporting requirements.

Q: How do I provide the information?
A: The information can be easily updated in BAE. Once you have logged in, you will click on the “View Regulatory Data” link on the left side of the home page. The information you need to update will be highlighted in red, and then you select from a drop-down menu and enter/confirm your data.

Q: What are my options if I don’t want to use BAE?
A: EIN information needs to be collected on BAE. However, if you are unable to access BAE or need to submit a correction to information you have already entered into BAE, you can contact the Dedicated Group Data Collection line at 855-804-3635. You can select “Group,” then “Administrator,” and then select option four “Number” to provide their EIN.

Q: What is the deadline for providing this information?
A: We are asking that groups provide this information within 30 days of receiving an email notification or letter. Groups who do not complete their data within that time frame will be sent a follow-up email.

This communication is intended for informational purposes only. It is not intended to provide, does not constitute, and cannot be relied upon as legal, tax or compliance advice. The information contained in this communication is subject to change based on future regulation and guidance.

a:7:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{5593009a4ec3be27182185b2}s:11:"dateCreated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1435697306;s:4:"usec";i:418000;}s:5:"title";s:33:"Supreme Court Ruling on ObamaCare";s:4:"date";s:8:"06/30/15";s:3:"uri";s:34:"/supreme-court-ruling-on-obamacare";s:7:"content";s:102679:"

Leading the News

Supreme Court Rules In Favor Of ACA Subsidies.

The Supreme Court  issued its decision in King v. Burwell yesterday, voting 6-3 to uphold the Affordable Care Act’s subsidies in states using the Federal marketplace. Chief Justice John Roberts and Justice Anthony Kennedy joined with the high court’s liberal wing in the majority opinion. Media analyses cast the ruling as a major victory for the ACA, cementing its role in the healthcare system and validating President Obama’s signature achievement. Coverage led all three broadcast network newscasts, which combined for nearly 17 minutes of coverage, with NBC devoting nearly eight minutes to the subject, more than twice as much as ABC.

        ABC World News (6/25, lead story, 2:25, Muir) called it a “historic ruling” bringing “very strong reaction tonight on both sides. ... Many tonight pointing to” Roberts, “twice now saving Obamacare.” Terry Moran called it “a stunning 6-3 decision” that “saved the linchpin of the President’s healthcare law.” The CBS Evening News (6/25, lead story, 3:15, Pelley) said the ACA “was saved from a devastating blow,” and like ABC said “the conservative Chief Justice of the United States rescued for the second time the largest part of President Obama’s legacy. ... The President said today, ‘Now Obamacare is woven into the fabric of America.’” On NBC Nightly News (6/25, lead story, 4:05, Holt), Pete Williams reported, “This is the second time the US Supreme Court has bailed out Obamacare – this time, even more decisively than it did three years ago.” On CNN’s Situation Room (6/25), Wolf Blitzer called the ruling “a huge victory for President Obama.”

        The Washington Post  (6/26, Sun) reports that after the Supreme Court handed down its decision, “the big question that raced through political and policy circles, especially Republican ones, was: What happens now?” According to the Post, “not much” can impact the ACA in the near future. Despite their renewed interest in repealing the health law, congressional Republicans “know any such effort would face a certain veto from President Obama” and “they are far from united on any particular plan.” While there are other legal challenges to the law, “none poses as serious a threat as King v. Burwell.” Still, some GOP lawmakers yesterday reiterated calls for targeting unpopular provisions, “including taxes on medical devices and on the most generous health plans.”

        The New York Times  (6/26, A1, Liptak, Subscription Publication) reports on its front page that the high court’s ruling “means that it is all but certain that the Affordable Care Act will survive after Mr. Obama leaves office in 2017.” The Times says the decision also represents a “sweeping vindication that endorsed the larger purpose of Mr. Obama’s signature legislative achievement.” The article describes the ruling to uphold the subsidies as a “blow” to Republicans, though House Speaker John Boehner (R-OH) “vowed that the political fight against it would continue.”

        The Los Angeles Times  (6/26, Levey), in an analysis, concludes that with the Supreme Court’s “decisive” ruling yesterday, the ACA “is now virtually assured of surviving as a permanent feature of the American healthcare system.” Republicans’ chances of repealing the law “all but evaporated after the strongly worded decision.” Moreover, with “no serious Republican alternatives and a historic expansion in medical coverage well underway, Obamacare is about as firmly ensconced as a new law can be in a politically divided country.”

        USA Today  (6/26, Wolf, Heath) reports the ruling put the “landmark 2010 statute on solid legal footing for the immediate future.”

        A Politico  (6/25, Wheaton) analysis piece says that the Supreme Court “cemented President Barack Obama’s signature domestic achievement” by upholding the ACA on Thursday, while the AP  (6/26, Sherman) reports the Supreme Court “sent a clear message Thursday that President Barack Obama’s health care overhaul is here to stay.” Politico  (6/26, Dovere) reports in another article that President Obama’s recent victories on trade and now the ACA “feel particularly sweet...because they represent to Obama and his aides that his presidency has made gains and advances that aren’t just about cleaning up the mess they were left with in 2008.” A Wall Street Journal  (6/26, Lee, Nelson, Subscription Publication) highlights both victories under the headline “Obama Has a Good Week.”

        Meanwhile, USA Today  (6/26, Heath) reports that the legal attacks on the ACA “aren’t over,” but few remaining challenges “are broad enough to cripple the health law even if they succeed.” Republican lawmakers have sued over delays in implementing the employer mandate, while another suit “says Congress violated a little-known section of the Constitution about which chamber must introduce tax bills first.” Other challenges target the law’s contraception mandate.

        A second Washington Post  (6/26, Nakamura) article says the Supreme Court’s 6-3 decision in favor of the law “was a cheerful moment” for the Administration that “brought an emerging domestic legacy into sharper focus.” During a Rose Garden speech yesterday, President Obama “looked to history, to the great milestones of American liberalism — Social Security and Medicare — and placed his achievement firmly among them.” The Post adds that the court ruling “provided a jolt of enthusiasm that, with 18 months left in his tenure, Obama’s domestic achievements are accumulating just as his governing record is being scrutinized in the crucible of an election season to pick his successor.”

        The Wall Street Journal  (6/26, A1, Kendall, Radnofsky, Subscription Publication) reports on its front page that the Supreme Court’s decision, written by Chief Justice John Roberts, frustrated what conservatives saw as their best and perhaps last chance to deliver a fatal blow to the health law.

        The Christian Science Monitor  (6/26) reports that supporters of the law “say further steps are needed to achieve its goals of expanded access to insurance and affordable costs,” while critics “point to data that suggest premiums in many locales are poised to rise considerably next year and beyond.” It also remains to be seen whether more Republican-led states will opt to expand Medicaid eligibility under the law.

        Politico  (6/26, Magazine) interviewed a number of “leading thinkers in health care policy” on the future of the ACA following the Supreme Court ruling.

        Also covering the story are the Washington Times  (6/26, Howell), the Huffington Post  (6/25, Young), Kaiser Health News  (6/25), and US News & World Report  (6/25).

        Conservatives Angered By Roberts’ Vote To Save ACA. The Washington Post  (6/26, A1, Barnes) reports on its front page that with his vote to uphold the ACA, Chief Justice Roberts “again helped sustain the president’s policy legacy in a way that few could have anticipated when Obama took office.” The Post suggests that the legacies of the Obama presidency “and the Roberts court are forever intertwined.” According to the article, conservatives are “wondering whether they had misjudged Roberts a decade ago when he was nominated for the court.”

        A number of outlets examine Roberts’ decision to uphold the Affordable Care Act for the second time since 2012.

        According to a front-page Wall Street Journal  (6/26, A1, Kendall, Subscription Publication) article, the move angered Republicans who claimed the chief justice has moved away from conservative principles. Rep. Matt Salmon (R-AZ) questioned whether Roberts could even be considered a conservative “in any way, shape or form right now,” while Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX) blasted the “robed Houdinis” on the court who have “rewritten the text of Obamacare in order to impose this failed law on millions of Americans.”

        While criticizing the high court’s ruling in general, Sen. Orrin Hatch (R-UT) praised Roberts as a “remarkable judge” and a “tremendous human being” who wrote a “very clever opinion” on the ACA, The Hill  (6/26, Carney) reports in its “Floor Action” blog.

        Politico  (6/26, Gerstein) reports that Roberts’ decision to side with the Obama Administration and write the majority opinion in King v. Burwell “threw a huge splash of fuel onto a long-simmering debate about whether Republicans misjudged the chief justice when he was nominated a decade ago or whether he has grown more moderate in his years on the court.”

        The Washington Post  (6/26, Barnes) reports on its front page that Scalia said Roberts “performed ‘somersaults of statutory interpretation’ to save the act.”

        Several other outlets cover Scalia’s “scathing dissent,” as Fox News  (6/25) puts it.

        The Washington Post  (6/26, Schwarz) “The Fix” blog, for example, says Scalia called the decision “interpretive jiggery-pokery” and “pure applesauce,” adding that “words no longer have meaning if an Exchange that is not established by a State is ‘established by the State.’”

        CNN  (6/25, Collinson) reports that in his dissent, “Scalia effectively accused Roberts, Kennedy and fellow justices Stephen Breyer, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Elena Kagan and Sonia Sotomayor of saving the ACA for political reasons.”

        Reuters  (6/26, Biskupic) reports Scalia quipped that the law might as well be called “SCOTUScare.”

        Meanwhile, Rep. Brian Babin (R-TX) introduced a bill, “piggy-backing off Justice Antonin Scalia’s sarcasm, that would require all the justices and their clerks to get their health coverage through an Obamacare program as members of Congress and their staffs already do,” the Washington Post  (6/26, Itkowitz) reports. The Hill  (6/26, Hensch) “Floor Action” blog reports Babin said, “By eliminating their exemption from ObamaCare, they will see firsthand what the American people are forced to live with.”

        Also covering the story are The Hill  (6/26, Ferris), National Journal  (6/26, Baker, Subscription Publication), Politico  (6/26, Lerner), the Washington Times  (6/26, Dinan), the Washington Examiner  (6/26), the Daily Caller  (6/26, Smith), MSNBC  (6/26), TIME  (6/26), Fox News  (6/25), and the Wall Street Journal  (6/26, Palazzolo) “Law Blog.”

        Obama: ACA Is “Here To Stay.” Several outlets offer continuing coverage of the President’s Rose Garden speech yesterday.

        Bloomberg News  (6/26) reports that Obama “hailed” the Supreme Court’s decision, saying, “This is not an abstract thing any more, this is not a set of political talking points – this is reality.” Joined by Vice President Joe Biden and HHS Secretary Burwell, Obama stated, “We’ve got more work to do but what we’re not going to do is unravel what has now been woven into the fabric of America.”

        Reuters  (6/26, Hurley) reports that Obama said, “After more than 50 votes in Congress to repeal or weaken this law, after a presidential election based in part on preserving or repealing this law, after multiple challenges to this law before the Supreme Court, the Affordable Care Act is here to stay.”

        CNN  (6/25, Liptak, Producer) and Kaiser Health News  (6/26) also report the story.

        GOP Presidential Candidates, Other Lawmakers Attack Ruling. Nancy Cordes reported on the CBS Evening News (6/25, story 2, 2:15, Pelley) that “as Democrats cheered, Republican candidates raced to show their fury, calling the decision outrageous and an out-of-control act of judicial tyranny. ... Texas Sen. Ted Cruz called the court ‘lawless,’” though “so far, just two of the 13 [GOP] candidates, Florida’s Marco Rubio and Louisiana’s Bobby Jindal, have introduced their own plans to replace Obamacare.” On NBC Nightly News (6/25, story 3, 1:15, Holt), Chuck Todd said, “You saw Republican presidential candidates from Jeb Bush to Marco Rubio and in particular Ted Cruz all pledging to say that if elected, that this presidential election is now about the last chance you have to stop Obamacare or to repeal Obamacare.”

        CNN  (6/25, Lobianco) offers a rundown of GOP presidential candidates’ statements on the Supreme Court decision. Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-SC) said the ruling “only reinforces why we need a President who will bring about real reform that repeals Obamacare and replaces it with a plan that expands consumer choice, increases coverage, delivers better value for the dollar, and gives states more control, without stifling job creation.” Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal (R), meanwhile, said he is the only candidate that’s offered “a comprehensive plan” to replace the ACA.

        Reuters  (6/25) reports that House Speaker Boehner (R-OH) said Wednesday that Republicans have not yet decided whether to try to repeal the ACA using budget reconciliation. Speaking to reporters after the Supreme Court decision Thursday, Boehner said, “Listen, Obamacare is fundamentally broken. ... And so the struggle will continue.” The Washington Times  (6/26, Howell) reports that the GOP “had been hoping to use a ruling against the administration as a way to move away from Obamacare, likely through reconciliation.”

        Politico  (6/26, Bade) reports that Republicans are divided over reconciliation, as they would have to find “huge spending cuts” to pay for a repeal. Moreover, “some are uneasy about voting for repeal without offering a replacement to help Americans pay for insurance.”

        The Washington Examiner  (6/26) reports Boehner added, “We will continue our efforts to repeal the law and replace it with patient-centered solutions that meet the needs of seniors, small business owners, and middle-class families.”

        An article on the NBC News  (6/26) website considers how Republicans will move forward on the ACA in the wake of the King ruling, suggesting that while it’s unlikely many Republican politicians “will openly embrace the law,” the GOP “could execute a quiet, de-facto surrender” by embracing Medicaid expansion and focusing more on efforts to “replace,” rather than repeal, the law.

        A McClatchy  (6/26, Lightman) analysis concludes that the GOP will need to win the presidency in 2016 to have any chance of repealing the ACA. Even then, the Supreme Court’s ruling yesterday will “make it hard for Republicans to claim 2016 as a mandate for health care change.”

        Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus said the country “will need to elect Republican leaders with proven ideas and real solutions” in order to “fix our broken health-care system,” The Hill  (6/25, Kamisar) reports in its “Blog Briefing Room.”

        The Hill  (6/26, Sullivan, Ferris), meanwhile, says the high court’s decision puts Republicans “back to square one in their fight against ObamaCare.”

        Also covering GOP reactions to the King ruling are the Los Angeles Times  (6/25), the Huffington Post  (6/26, Bobic), the New Orleans Times-Picayune  (6/26), the AP  (6/26, Fram), Politico  (6/26, Everett), The Hill  (6/26, Carney), the Washington Post  (6/26, Zezima) “Post Politics” blog, National Journal  (6/26, Subscription Publication) and a second piece from National Journal  (6/26, Subscription Publication).

        Some GOP Leaders Reportedly “Relieved” Over Ruling Despite Public Displeasure. On ABC World News (6/25, story 3, 1:00, Muir), Jon Karl said, “Publicly, Republicans are expressing outrage over this ruling, but privately, many Republican leaders are breathing a sigh of relief, because if this ruling had gone the other way, more than six million Americans, most of them from states with Republican governors, would have lost their healthcare subsidies, and Republicans were deeply divided about what to do about it.”

        The Washington Post  (6/26, Tumulty) also says in a front-page article that GOP leaders “were privately relieved” because they “were spared the challenge of having to come up with a solution” for those who would lose coverage. In addition, “as it moves into a presidential election season, the party can continue to galvanize the conservative base by railing against both the law and the high court.” The Wall Street Journal  (6/26, Hook, Subscription Publication) says, however, that the ruling does put greater pressure on Republicans to propose legislative alternatives to the ACA.

        The New York Times  (6/26, Goodnough, Tavernise, Subscription Publication) says “most Republican governors reaffirmed their opposition to the healthcare law in statements reacting to the decision,” though some “had something positive to say.” Tennessee Gov. Bill Haslam, who failed in an attempt to expand Medicaid under the ACA earlier this year, said, “I am pleased for those folks who have insurance subsidies. While philosophically I didn’t agree with their ruling, in terms of the smoothness of the market and people obtaining coverage in a predictable way, I think that’s a good thing.”

        The Hill  (6/26, Lillis) reports that Democrats applauding the high court’s decision yesterday “are suggesting that even Republican opponents of the law are relieved by the ruling.” The Hill explains that a ruling against the subsidies “would have put the Republican supporters of the lawsuit in the punishing position of devising a new system to get those people new coverage — or face the blame for the spike in the uninsured rate heading into the 2016 elections.” Rep. Steny Hoyer (D-MD), the Democratic whip, said, “The Republicans have just been saved from themselves by the Supreme Court of the United States.”

        Meanwhile, Rep. Chris Van Hollen (D-MD) called on Republican to abandon their “numbskull quest” to kill the ACA, The Hill  (6/26, Kamisar) “Blog Briefing Room” reports, adding, “The reality of the matter is, they’ve got no ideas for how to fill the giant hole that would have been left if the Supreme Court had ruled the other way.”

        Insurers Breathe Easy As Health Stocks Soar On King Ruling. The Wall Street Journal  (6/26, A1, Mathews, Subscription Publication) reports on its front page that insurance companies are expressing relief, since the ruling gives them some stability in implementation of the ACA, and also guarantees extended business from marketplace buyers. In an analysis, the New York Times  (6/26, Pear, Sanger-Katz, Subscription Publication) writes that the subsidies “average $272 a month, or $3,264 a year, and cover nearly three-fourths of the average premium for people receiving assistance.”

        The Washington Post  (6/26, Bogage) reports in its “Wonkblog” that healthcare investors “are cheering the Supreme Court’s ruling” on the ACA. Health insurers and hospitals saw their stocks surge immediately after the ruling. HCA Holdings, for example, “was up 9 percent after the ruling,” and Cigna Health “rose nearly 4 percent.” Likewise, CNN Money  (6/25) reports that healthcare investors “see the ruling as a major win for hospitals because more of their clients will have insurance, which should make hospitals more profitable.”

        Bloomberg News  (6/25) reports that with King v. Burwell “out of the way, health insurers and hospitals can get back to making deals.” Indeed, Bill Bithoney, a managing director in the consulting firm BDO USA’s health-care advisory practice, said uncertainty over the case “was the biggest obstacle to M&A that existed in the health-care industry.”

        Fox Business  (6/25) reports that Universal Health Services CEO Alan Miller said he “wasn’t surprised” by the ruling upholding the ACA. He added, “We’ve seen that with ObamaCare, our bad debt and uncompensated care has gone down about 25%. We take care of patients in a very good way and now we’ll get more pay for it.”

        US News & World Report  (6/25) and the Washington Times  (6/25, Weiss) also report the story.

        Consumers Relieved By High Court Ruling. The Washington Post  (6/26, Gebelhoff) reports on several consumers “who expressed relief that the court sided with the Obama administration in the highly anticipated King v. Burwell decision.” Had the court ruled against the ACA, an estimated 6.4 million Americans on the Federal exchange would have lost their subsidies.

        The AP  (6/26, Johnson) reports, however, that consumers’ “sense of reprieve is tinged with worry about the ongoing high cost of health care and the coverage offered through the government exchanges.”

        A piece on the Washington Post  (6/26, Ross) “The Fix” blog reports on “what we know” about the millions of Americans who faced the greatest risk of losing healthcare coverage, citing a recent Urban Institute report.

        NBC Nightly News (6/25, story 2, 2:25, Holt) ran a feature on some of those covered under the ACA that was sympathetic to supporters of the law, saying “the Obamacare law [is] directly affecting so many families who say it’s been quite literally a lifesaver.”

        Additional Media Coverage. Other national outlets covering the Supreme Court’s decision in King v. Burwell include the Los Angeles Times  (6/25, Savage), Bloomberg News  (6/26, Deprez, Olorunnipa), McClatchy  (6/26, Doyle, Pugh), Reuters  (6/26, Oliphant), Bloomberg Politics  (6/25, Harris), Bloomberg Politics  (6/25, House, Hunter), the Boston Globe  (6/26, Linskey), the Washington Examiner  (6/26, Drucker), the AP  (6/26, Espo), the Bloomberg Politics  (6/26, Kapur, Weigel), the Huffington Post  (6/25), the Los Angeles Times  (6/26, Savage), the Wall Street Journal  (6/26, Bravin, Subscription Publication), National Journal  (6/26, Baker, Subscription Publication), NPR  (6/25), the Wall Street Journal  (6/26, Gershman), CNBC  (6/26, Mangan), MSNBC  (6/26), PBS NewsHour  (6/26), the Washington Post  (6/26, Ehrenfreund), Politico  (6/26, Cheney), Roll Call  (6/26, Bowman), Politico  (6/25, Haberkorn, Gerstein), the Los Angeles Times  (6/26, Terhune), and the Daily Caller  (6/26, Weaver).

a:7:{s:3:"_id";C:7:"MongoId":24:{559402474ec3beaf352185ae}s:11:"dateCreated";O:9:"MongoDate":2:{s:3:"sec";i:1435763271;s:4:"usec";i:882000;}s:5:"title";s:33:"Anthem Certification Portal Open!";s:4:"date";s:8:"07/01/15";s:3:"uri";s:33:"/anthem-certification-portal-open";s:7:"content";s:3810:"

Our Anthem Certification Portal Is Now Open!

July 1, 2015

 

 

Certify now and get ready to boost your sales and income! To access our Certification portal and get started today, click here: Get certified now!

Don’t miss the chance to sell our reliable, affordable Medicare Advantage and Medicare Supplement plans during the 2016 Annual Enrollment Period (AEP) and be entered in our Seize the Dream Sweepstakes!

The faster you act, the more entries you earn. Begin preparing for a successful AEP season and get certified now!

Why certify with Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield?

  • You can complete your AHIP training as early as July 1, 2015.
  • Save up to $50.00! Brokers who login to AHIP via a designated Anthem link will pay $125, which is a discounted rate from the standard $175.
  • Completing your certification through our portal early allows you to pre-order 2016 Medicare Advantage and PDP enrollment kits.*
  • Early certifiers ONLY can pre-order enrollment kits between August 1 and August 31.* What's more, as we get close to October 1, those preorders will get delivered first!
  • With kits in hand when AEP kicks off, you won't miss a single opportunity when thousands of prospects are shopping for coverage. 

We offer certification and so much more!

Along with certification and support, Anthem’s broad portfolio of plans helps you meet the needs of more clients with a wide range of proven, consumer-trusted, Medicare Advantage Plans and Prescription Drug Plans, in addition to Medicare Supplement coverage. Offer your clients a plan demonstrating decades of stability and reliability, providing them with valuable peace of mind.

All in all, we simply make it easier to build your book of business and diversify your portfolio. When you successfully finish your 2016 training, you are also certified for 2015.

The opportunity is now. The possibilities are endless.

Questions?

Contact Agent Services by email at medicareagentsupport@anthem.com or by phone 1-800-633-4368.

*Agents must have current licensure, certification and appointment in every state they sell in to be eligible for commission payment of sales or pre-order/order Medicare Advantage and Prescription Drug Plan enrollment kits. In order to receive commissions on your sales or renewals for 2016, you must keep a current licensure and appointment, and finish the 2016 certification.

Not connected with or endorsed by the U.S. Government or the federal Medicare program.
